description.narrative: Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 International Alert is an independent peacebuilding non-governmental organisation with a global mission to work with people in conflict-affected and -threatened areas to make a positive difference for peace; to improve the substance and implementation of international policies relevant to peacebuilding; and to strengthen the peacebuilding sector, with a key focus on gender, prevention of violent extremism and economic development for peace. Its main methods of engagement include bringing people together through dialogue; capacity building through trainings, accompaniment (which involves offering continuous guidance and advice to people, organisations and companies as they build peace or operate in high-risk places) and undertaking policy research and advocacy. With Headquarters in London, United Kingdom, Alert is active in 27 countries and territories across all continents.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 International Alert är en oberoende och icke-statlig organisation med globalt fredsbyggande uppdrag att arbeta med människor i konflikt-drabbade och -hotade områden för att ha en positiv inverkan för fred, att stärka grunden och implementeringen av internationella policies som är relevanta för fredsbyggande, och att stärka den fredsbyggande sektor, med ett tydligt fokus på jämställdhet, förebyggande av våldsam extremism och ekonomisk utveckling för fred. Dess huvudsakliga arbetssätt är att föra människor samman via dialog, kapacitetsutveckling via utbildningar, medföljande (vilket innebär att ge löpande vägledning och råd till människor, organisationer och företag när de bygger fred eller verkar i högriskområden) och att genomföra policyforskning och påverkansarbete. Alert har huvudkontor i London, Storbritannien och är aktiv i 27 länder och områden över alla kontinenter.

The overall objectives of the intervention are shown below. This is the mission statement of International Alert, which informs the Strategic Perspective 2015-2019 and which will guide the new strategy from 2020. The overall objectives are: 1.) to work with people in conflict-affected and -threatened areas to make a positive difference for peace 2.) to improve the substance and implementation of international policies relevant to peacebuilding 3.) to strengthen the peacebuilding sector. Based on this, the Strategic Perspective outlines six Pathways: Relations within and between communities (1); State-Citizen Relations (2); Gender relations (3); Crime, violence and instability (CVI) (4); Natural Resource Management and Climate Change (5); and Economic development for peace (6). Each pathway has a specific set of expected results, which guides all work of Alert. A country or regional programme may contribute to one or several of the pathways.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

tag.narrative: 1.2 - By 2030, reduce at least by half the proportion of men, women and children of all ages living in poverty in all its dimensions according to national definitions.
1.2 - Till 2030 minst halvera den andel män, kvinnor och barn i alla åldrar som lever i någon form av fattigdom enligt nationella definitioner.

11.7 - Senast 2030 tillhandahålla universell tillgång till säkra, inkluderande och tillgängliga grönområden och offentliga platser, i synnerhet för kvinnor och barn, äldre personer och personer med funktionsnedsättning.
11.7 - By 2030, provide universal access to safe, inclusive and accessible, green and public spaces, in particular for women and children, older persons and persons with disabilities.
16.1 - Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere.
16.1 - Avsevärt minska alla former av våld och dödligt våld överallt.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.

description.narrative: In 2019, International Alert reports that the organisation ran projects in 21 countries and territories, with training, research or one-off consultancies and business partnerships in a further 18. In total, Alert implemented 114 projects, 21 of which took place across multiple regions. Throughout the year, together with its partners, the organisation engaged and supported 276,301 people through dialogue, training, advocacy, accompaniment, research and outreach activities. Of these, 52% were women and 47% were men, with just under 1% of people identifying as ‘other’or preferring not to reveal their gender identity. International Alert records the ways in which their work effects change by tracking project data and using outcome harvesting techniques. These results reflect the changes that take place in individuals, institutions and societies following our engagement – whether directly or indirectly. Alerts reports the following (where the intervention achieved multiple changes – for example, changing a person’s attitude and behaviour – Alert categorises it by the most relevant): - Changes in knowledge and attitudes: 41% of results- Changes in behaviour and processes: 41% of results- Changes in conditions (e.g. policies, structures, etc.): 18% of results In the 2019 reporting, International Alert illustrates its work with a number of results examples. For this year, Sida wishes to highlight how Alert has influenced policy in the area of global peace and security. Over 2019, Alert developed a strategic framework to guide the expansion of its policy influence, including setting out tangible steps for strengthening the capacity of the global team in this area. Two key cross-organisational themes were identified around which to leverage the influence over the coming two years: Gender Peace and Security (GPS); and making the case for peacebuilding. Alert used preparations for the 20th anniversary of UNSC Resolution 1325 on women, peace and security as a rallying point for the GPS agenda and set out a policy engagement plan underpinned by newly commissioned research on the impact of 1325. We were able to access a range of senior level policy makers in the German Parliament, launching a policy dialogue and make the case for peacebuilding by presenting the Alert’s Peace Perceptions Poll. Throughout 2019 International Alert also continued to advocate that environment and climate change considerations to be factored into peacebuilding policies and practices. This included raising awareness of the rising conflict risks related to access and control over water resources and protection of water ecosystems globally, as well as specifically in Mali, through our membership in the Water, Peace and Security Partnership. Alert represented the partnership at the Paris Peace Forum, where the partnership’s early warning tool on water-conflicts was presented.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
